Theatre for the Survivors

Jan 11, 2008


I find it fascinating when a play is written which attempts to depict the life of a recently deceased subject with living relatives. One example, Robert Brustein's Nobody Dies on Friday can elicit a very public backlash from critics and family members alike. ART's new production of Copenhagen has for it's subject Werner Heisenberg. In this case, the family is thrilled, as attested to by an email from Heisenberg's son, Jochen. From the ART blog:

This afternoon Kati Mitchell, our Director of Press and Public Relations, received a wonderful email from Jochen Heisenberg, Werner Heisenberg’s son, a professor of physics at the University of New Hampshire. Mr. Heisenberg attended Wednesday night’s performance of Copenhagen.

Read the letter here. Whether a work of art is reviled or revered by the family may not, and perhaps should not be a central concern for the author, director, and actors, but let's face it: reality and the feelings of survivors are going to enter into the mix at some point. This is bound to shape the artistic choices in the production - for the better, and possibly for the worse.
